title: Food Preparation — Celery and Peanut Butter
description: The child washes celery, cuts it into sticks, and fills them with peanut butter. This multi-step food preparation builds sequencing skills and independence.
instructions:
1. Wash hands together.
2. Show the celery. 'First we wash it under water.'
3. Place on the cutting board. Demonstrate cutting into sticks with a child-safe knife.
4. Scoop peanut butter with a small spreader and fill the celery channel.
5. Optional: add raisins on top ('ants on a log').
6. Enjoy the snack and clean up all materials.
materials_needed: Peanut butter or sunflower seed butter

slides.heading: Food Preparation
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! We are going to learn how to make a yummy snack. It's called "Food Preparation," and we'll be using celery and peanut butter.

slides.setup_instructions: Wash hands. Arrange all materials on a tray. Pre-wash the celery if needed.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we need for our special snack! We have crunchy celery sticks, yummy peanut butter, a special safe knife for cutting, a board to cut on, a little tool to spread with, and a plate for our snack. We also have little raisins if we want to make it extra fun! Can you help a grown-up find all these things?

slides.text: 'Today we are making a special snack with three steps: wash, cut, and spread!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today, we get to make a super cool snack! We have three important jobs to do: first, we'll wash everything, then we'll cut it, and last, we'll spread some yummy peanut butter. It's like a little cooking adventure!

slides.text: Step 1: Wash the celery under running water. Pat dry. Step 2: Place on the cutting board and cut into sticks.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for our first two steps! We need to give the celery a nice bath under the water, and then pat it dry. After that, we'll put it on our cutting board and use our safe knife to chop it into little sticks, just like tiny logs!

slides.text: Step 3: Use the spreader to scoop peanut butter. Fill the groove in the celery. 'The groove is like a little boat!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the best part! We get to use our special spreader to scoop out some smooth peanut butter. Then, we'll fill up the middle part of the celery stick, like filling up a little boat with yummy treasure!

slides.text: Optional: place raisins on top. 'These are called ants on a log! The celery is the log, and the raisins are the ants.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! If you want, we can put some tiny raisins on top of the peanut butter. It makes our snack look like a little log with ants walking on it – how silly and fun!

slides.prompt: Prepare 3-4 celery sticks on your own. Follow all three steps: wash, cut, spread. Add raisins if you like!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the super snack maker! You get to do all the steps yourself: wash the celery, cut it into sticks, and spread the peanut butter. You can even add the little raisins if you like! I know you can do it!

slides.text: Enjoy your snack! Wash the cutting board, knife, and spreader. Wipe down your workspace.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete all three preparation steps independently?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You made your own special celery and peanut butter snack all by yourself! Wasn't that fun? Now let's eat our yummy creation and then help clean up our special cooking space.

parent_notes: This is a multi-step food preparation activity that builds sequencing and executive function skills. Substitute sunflower seed butter for nut-free households. The 'ants on a log' variation is motivating for young children. Let the child serve their creation to family members — serving others builds pride and social awareness.
household_substitutes: Ingredients as listed in the lesson
preparation_steps: Wash hands first. Set out all ingredients and tools before calling the child. Pre-wash produce.
control_of_error: The finished food item shows the result. Taste-testing is the best self-check!
extension_ideas: Let the child serve the food to family
Draw or write about what you made
Try a variation with different ingredients

title: Moveable Alphabet — Building CVC Words from Dictation
description: The child builds CVC words with the moveable alphabet as the adult slowly dictates them. This is the beginning of spelling from sound.
instructions:
1. 'I am going to say a word, and you will build it with the moveable alphabet.'
2. Say 'bed' slowly: /b/-/e/-/d/. Repeat naturally: 'bed.'
3. Child segments the sounds and finds each letter.
4. Say the next word: 'hop.' Then 'fun.' Then 'wig.' Then 'red.'
5. If the child struggles, say the word more slowly or help isolate the middle vowel.
6. Child reads each word back after building.

slides.heading: Moveable Alphabet
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun slide! It has a special name, "Moveable Alphabet," and it's all about building words. We're going to learn how to spell words by listening to them, just like a super detective!

slides.setup_instructions: Open the moveable alphabet. Clear a large work space for building multiple words.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these little letters! This is our "moveable alphabet," and these are like building blocks for words. We also have a special mat to put them on so they don't get lost. Ask a grown-up to help you open up all these letters and get our mat ready for some word-building fun!

slides.text: 'Today I will say words and you will build them! Listen carefully to each sound in the word.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today is super exciting because we get to play a listening game! I'm going to say a word, and your job is to listen very, very carefully to all the little sounds you hear inside the word. Then, you'll find the letters that make those sounds!

slides.text: Say 'bed' naturally. 'What sounds do you hear?' If needed, stretch it: /b/-/e/-/d/. Child finds b, e, d.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's try our first word. Listen: "bed." Can you hear the sounds? It's like /b/-/e/-/d/. Now, can you find the letters that make those sounds in our letter box and put them together on the mat to make the word "bed"?

slides.text: Continue with: hop, fun, wig, red, mug. Give the child time to think about each sound.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to do that for a few more words too! Listen for the sounds in "hop," then "fun," then "wig," and "red." Take your time to listen to each sound and find the right letter for it. You're doing so great!

slides.text: After building each word, child reads it back. 'You wrote it AND you can read it!'
slides.mascot_explanation: After you build each word with the letters, we'll read it together! You'll be able to look at the word you built and say it out loud. It's like magic – you built it, and now you can read it too!

slides.prompt: Build 5 words from dictation. Then choose 2 words and draw a picture for each one.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to build lots of words! I'll say them, and you listen for the sounds and find the letters. After you build them, you get to pick two of your favorite words and draw a picture for them. That will be so much fun!

slides.text: 'You are writing words from just hearing them! Your ears hear the sounds and your hands build the words.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build at least 3 out of 5 dictated CVC words?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are amazing! You listened so carefully and built words just by hearing the sounds. Your ears are super smart, and your hands are great at putting the letters together. You're a real word-building star!

parent_notes: Dictation is the bridge between encoding (spelling) and decoding (reading). The child must hear the word, segment it into sounds, and find the matching letters. The middle vowel sound is often the hardest to isolate. If the child writes 'bed' as 'bd,' they are hearing the consonants but missing the vowel — this is developmentally normal. Help by stretching the vowel: 'b-eeee-d.'

title: Linear Counting — 1 to 20
description: The child practices counting objects in a line from 1 to 20, connecting one-to-one correspondence with the newly learned teen numbers.
instructions:
1. Set out 20 small objects in a long line.
2. Count together, touching each: 1, 2, 3... up to 20.
3. The child counts independently.
4. Practice cardinality: 'How many are there in all?' (20)
5. 'Give me 14.' Child counts out 14.
6. 'Give me 17.' Continue with various teen numbers.
materials_needed: Counting mat or long strip of paper

slides.heading: Linear Counting
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Linear Counting," and that means we're going to learn how to count things in a long line, all the way up to the big number 20! We're going to be super counters!

slides.setup_instructions: Line up 20 objects in a row. Have numeral cards available.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, friend, let's get our special counting stuff ready! We need 20 little things to count, like blocks or buttons, and a long strip of paper or a mat to put them on in a line. We also need some number cards, like little signs for each number. Ask your grown-up to help you find these things!

slides.text: 'Let's count all the way to 20! Touch each object as we count together.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's start counting together! We're going to touch each little thing *one* time as we say its number, starting from the beginning of the line. We'll count all the way to 20, so let's get ready!

slides.text: Count slowly together: '1, 2, 3... 10, 11, 12... 20!' Touch each object exactly once.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is how we count super carefully! We touch each thing *just once* and say its number: 1, 2, 3... and keep going all the way until we get to 20. It's like giving each thing a little pat and a name!

slides.text: 'How many objects are there altogether?' (20) 'The last number you say is the TOTAL.'
slides.mascot_explanation: After we touch all the things, the very last number we say is how many things there are *altogether*! So if we count all the way to 20, that means there are 20 things in our line! That last number tells us the total.

slides.text: Place numeral cards next to groups: 'Here is the card for 10. Here is 15. Here is 20.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See these number cards? They are like helpers for our counting! This one is for 10, this one is for 15, and this one is for 20. We can put them next to our line of things to show how many we have.

slides.prompt: 'Give me 14!' Count out 14 objects. 'Give me 17!' Continue with different teen numbers.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the boss of counting! Your grown-up will say "Give me 14!" and you have to count out 14 things. Then they might say "Give me 17!" and you count out 17. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You can count to 20! And you can count out ANY number up to 20!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child count to 20 with one-to-one correspondence and count out specific quantities?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You can count all the way to 20, and you can even pick out any number of things you want up to 20! You are such a super counter, and counting out those numbers was the best!

parent_notes: Linear counting to 20 bridges the gap between rote counting (saying the numbers) and rational counting (understanding quantity). The 'give me' game tests whether the child truly understands what teen numbers mean. If the child counts out 14 correctly, they understand that 14 is a specific quantity. Practice counting objects in daily life: stairs, toys, grapes, books.

title: Puzzle Map — North America
description: Introduction to the North America puzzle map. The child learns the names and locations of the countries within North America.
instructions:
1. Present the North America puzzle map.
2. 'This is the continent where we live! Let's learn about the countries inside it.'
3. Remove the United States piece. 'This is the United States.' Replace it.
4. Remove Canada: 'This is Canada — our neighbor to the north.'
5. Remove Mexico: 'Mexico is our neighbor to the south.'
6. Introduce 2-3 Central American countries or Caribbean islands.

slides.heading: Puzzle Map
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun picture! It shows us a special puzzle map. This puzzle map is all about where we live, called North America!

slides.setup_instructions: Place the North America map on a table. Have the world map nearby for context.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we need some special things for our game today! We have a puzzle map of North America, which is like a big shape with pieces. We also have another map that shows all of the world, and a picture of what the puzzle looks like when it's all finished.

slides.text: Show North America on the world map: 'This is the continent where we live. Now let's look INSIDE it!'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this big map? It shows the whole world! We live on a special part of it called a continent, and this part is called North America. Let's look closer at all the cool countries inside!

slides.text: Remove the United States: 'This is the United States — it's where we live!' Discuss its shape. Replace it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, watch this! We're taking out a piece of the puzzle. This piece is shaped like the United States, and that's where our home is! Can you see how it fits right back in?

slides.text: Remove Canada: 'Canada is very big! It's north of us.' Remove Mexico: 'Mexico is south of us.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to find two more big pieces! This big one is Canada, and it's way up north from us. And this one is Mexico, which is south of where we live.

slides.text: Introduce Guatemala or Cuba if the child is interested. 'North America has many countries!'
slides.mascot_explanation: North America has even more countries than just those three big ones! Sometimes there are smaller places like Guatemala or Cuba that are also part of our big continent.

slides.prompt: Take out the three big countries. Can you put them back? Name each one as you place it.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to play! Can you help me put the three big countries back into the puzzle map? Let's say their names together as we find their special spots. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You know the countries of North America! United States, Canada, and Mexico.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and place the three main North American countries?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did such a great job learning about our continent! You know all about the United States, Canada, and Mexico. You're a super geographer!

parent_notes: Moving from the world map to a continent map zooms in on detail. The child learns that continents contain countries. Focus on the three largest countries first. If your family has connections to other North American countries, feature those as well. Puzzle maps build spatial awareness and fine motor skills through the knob-grasping.

title: Read-Aloud: The Ugly Vegetables by Grace Lin
description: Reading 'The Ugly Vegetables' by Grace Lin, a story about a girl who helps her mother plant a Chinese vegetable garden that looks different from the neighbors' flower gardens.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'What do you see growing here? Do these look like regular gardens?'
2. Read aloud with warmth — the narrator's initial embarrassment and ultimate pride.
3. Discuss: 'Why was she embarrassed at first? What changed her mind?'
4. Talk about different kinds of beauty — flowers are pretty, but vegetables become delicious soup.
5. Discuss cultural foods: 'What special foods does your family make?'
6. Connect to diversity: different isn't ugly, it's wonderful.
materials_needed: The Ugly Vegetables by Grace Lin
Optional: vegetables from the story to examine

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: The Ugly Vegetables by Grace Lin
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, this is the book we're going to read! It's called "The Ugly Vegetables," and it's written by a nice lady named Grace Lin. We're going to read a story together about a special garden!

items: Optional: Chinese vegetables to see and touch
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready in a comfortable reading spot.
slides.mascot_explanation: To get ready for our story, we need a few things! We need our special book, "The Ugly Vegetables," and maybe some real vegetables if you have them. Can you ask your grown-up to help you find the book and maybe a yummy carrot or some green beans?

slides.text: Cover: 'This garden looks different from the other gardens on the street. Let's find out why!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're looking at the cover of our book! See how the garden looks a little different from other gardens? Let's look closely and wonder why it might be special.

slides.text: Read with expression — show the contrast between the pretty flower gardens and the 'ugly' vegetable garden.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for me to read the story to you! I'll use my voice to show you how the girl felt about her garden at first, and then how she felt later. Listen closely to the story!

slides.text: Discuss: 'Why did the girl think her garden was ugly? What happened when the soup was ready? How did the neighbors react?'
slides.mascot_explanation: After we read, let's talk about the story! Why do you think the girl felt a little shy about her garden at first? And what happened when her family made soup? What did the neighbors think then?

slides.prompt: Draw two gardens side by side — a flower garden and a vegetable garden. Which one can you eat? What vegetables would you plant?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this fun activity! We get to draw two gardens. First, draw a garden with pretty flowers. Then, draw a garden with yummy vegetables! Which garden can we eat? What kind of vegetables do you want to plant?

slides.text: 'The vegetables weren't ugly at all — they were delicious! Sometimes the best things look different from what we expect.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why the 'ugly' vegetables turned out to be wonderful?
slides.mascot_explanation: We finished our story and our drawing! See? The vegetables weren't ugly at all, they were super yummy and made delicious soup! Sometimes things that look different are the most wonderful things. You did a great job listening and drawing!

parent_notes: This story celebrates cultural diversity, gardening, and the idea that beauty comes in many forms. Grace Lin's autobiographical story introduces Chinese vegetables and cooking. It connects to Montessori themes of respect for cultures, food preparation, and nature study. The recipe at the back of the book can be a cooking activity.
household_substitutes: The book mentioned in the lesson
preparation_steps: Choose a cozy spot. Preview the book before reading it aloud.
control_of_error: Discussion-based — ask open-ended questions about the story.
extension_ideas: Draw a favorite scene
Retell the story in your own words
Act out a scene together

title: Baric Tablets — Introduction
description: Introduction to the Montessori baric tablets. The child discriminates between tablets of different weights using only the sense of touch with a blindfold.
instructions:
1. Present three sets of baric tablets: light (balsa), medium (maple), heavy (walnut).
2. Hold one light and one heavy tablet. 'Feel the difference? One is light and one is heavy.'
3. Three-period lesson: 'This is light. This is heavy. Which is heavier?'
4. Introduce the medium tablet.
5. Blindfold the child. Hand them tablets one at a time to sort by weight.
6. Sort all tablets into three groups: light, medium, heavy.
materials_needed: Baric tablets (3 sets of different weights)

slides.heading: Baric Tablets
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to learn about things that feel light, medium, and heavy. It's like feeling a little feather, then a toy block, then maybe a big book!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay all tablets on a mat. If DIY, use wood pieces of the same size but different density or weight.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these special flat blocks! These are our baric tablets, and they feel different in our hands. We also have a soft blindfold so we can really use our super-duper touchy-feely fingers, and a mat to keep everything tidy.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to use our hands to feel WEIGHT. Close your eyes and hold this.' Place a heavy tablet in each hand, then a light one.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's put on our listening ears and get ready to feel! We're going to close our eyes so we can feel with our hands. Your teacher will put one tablet in each hand, and then another one, so you can feel how different they are.

slides.text: 'Which one is heavier? Which is lighter? You can tell just by how they feel!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think with our hands! Can you feel which one feels like it's hugging your hand more? That's the heavier one, and the one that feels like it's floating is the lighter one.

slides.text: Three-period lesson: 'This is light.' 'This is heavy.' 'This is medium — in between.' 'Show me the heavy one.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to learn some special words for these! This one feels super light, so we call it 'light.' This one feels like a big hug, so it's 'heavy.' And this one is right in the middle, so it's 'medium'! Can you point to the heavy one?

slides.text: Blindfold: 'Now sort WITHOUT looking. Feel each tablet and put it with others that weigh the same.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the super fun part! We're going to put on the blindfold so we can't see, and just use our amazing sense of touch. Feel each tablet and try to put it with others that feel just like it.

slides.prompt: Sort all the tablets into three weight groups with the blindfold on. Check by looking when finished!
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, close your eyes again with the blindfold on! We need to feel each tablet very carefully and put them into three piles: light ones, medium ones, and heavy ones. When you're all done, we can peek and see if you sorted them just right!

slides.text: 'Your hands can feel differences in weight! You sorted them perfectly using just your sense of touch.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sort tablets into three weight categories?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! Your hands are so smart, they could feel the difference between light, medium, and heavy tablets all by themselves. You sorted them perfectly using just your touch – that's amazing!

parent_notes: Baric tablets isolate the baric sense (sense of weight). The blindfold removes visual cues, forcing the child to rely entirely on the feeling of weight. If you don't have Montessori baric tablets, create DIY versions by filling identical small boxes or bags with different amounts of sand or rice. This work develops the same discrimination used when judging if a bag is too heavy to carry.
household_substitutes: 3-6 identical small containers (film canisters or small boxes)
Coins, sand, or small rocks to add different weights
preparation_steps: Fill containers with different amounts of coins/sand to create varying weights. Seal with tape.
control_of_error: Number the containers on the bottom from lightest to heaviest. Child checks after sorting.
extension_ideas: Use a kitchen scale to verify weight order
Add more containers for finer discrimination
Compare household objects: "Which is heavier?"

title: Moveable Alphabet — Short Vowel Words (e and o)
description: Focused work building CVC words with the short /e/ and /o/ vowel sounds using the moveable alphabet.
instructions:
1. Review the five vowel sounds: /a/, /e/, /i/, /o/, /u/.
2. Focus on /e/: build bed, red, pen, hen, ten, let, net, wet.
3. 'What sound do you hear in the MIDDLE of all these words? /e/!'
4. Focus on /o/: build dog, hot, mop, pot, log, top, box, fox.
5. Mix /e/ and /o/ words. Child builds from dictation.
6. Child reads all built words.

slides.heading: Moveable Alphabet
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is our special box for making words! We're going to use it to learn about some funny sounds that happen in the middle of words, like in "bed" and "dog." It's going to be so much fun!

slides.setup_instructions: Open the moveable alphabet. Ensure plenty of vowel letters are available.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these little letter pieces! These are our "moveable alphabet" letters, and we'll use them to build words. We also have this special mat to put our letters on so they don't get lost. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these letters and the mat?

slides.text: Review vowels: 'a, e, i, o, u — the vowels! Every word needs at least one vowel.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's remember our special vowel friends: a, e, i, o, and u! They are like the heart of every word we say. We need them to make words sound just right.

slides.text: '/e/ words: listen — bed, red, pen. What sound is in the MIDDLE?' Build 'bed': /b/-/e/-/d/.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's listen really carefully to the sound in the middle of words like "bed" and "red." Hear that "eh" sound? That's our special /e/ sound! Let's use our letters to build the word "bed" together: b-e-d.

slides.text: Build more /e/ words: red, pen, hen, ten, let, net, wet. Read each one!
slides.mascot_explanation: You're doing so great with the /e/ sound! Let's keep practicing and build some more words that have that "eh" sound in the middle. We'll build "red," "pen," and "hen," and then we'll read them all together!

slides.text: Switch to /o/ words: dog, hot, mop, pot, log, top, box, fox. 'The middle sound is /o/!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's listen to a different middle sound! Hear the "oh" sound in "dog" and "hot"? That's our special /o/ sound! Let's use our letters to build words like "dog" and "mop," and we'll say the /o/ sound in the middle.

slides.prompt: I say a word, you build it! Mix /e/ and /o/ words: hot, pen, dog, red, mop, hen. Read them back!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's game time! I'll say a word, and you get to be the super builder and make it with our letters. We'll try words with the /e/ sound and the /o/ sound, and then we'll read them all back. You've got this!

slides.text: 'You are building words with ALL the short vowel sounds! /a/, /e/, /i/, /o/, /u/.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build and read CVC words with short /e/ and /o/?
slides.mascot_explanation: Hooray! You did such an amazing job building and reading words with both the /e/ and /o/ sounds! You are a word-building superstar, and you learned so much today. Remember how you made "dog" and "pen" all by yourself? That was awesome!

parent_notes: Short vowel sounds are the trickiest part of early reading because they sound similar. /e/ and /i/ are often confused, as are /o/ and /u/. Focusing on one vowel at a time helps the child tune in to subtle differences. If the child confuses /e/ and /i/, exaggerate the sounds and use key words: '/e/ like in egg, /i/ like in itch.'

title: Linear Counting — Counting Chains of 10
description: The child counts a ten-bead chain, practicing counting to 10 with concrete beads. Introduction to the concept of skip counting.
instructions:
1. Present the short bead chain (chain of 10).
2. Lay it straight on the mat.
3. Count each bead: 1, 2, 3... 10.
4. Place an arrow label at 5 and at 10.
5. 'This chain has 10 beads. We can also count by fives: 5, 10!'
6. The child counts the chain independently and places the arrow labels.

slides.heading: Counting Chains
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It's our special counting chain, and it has 10 beads on it, like fingers on two hands! We're going to have so much fun counting them together.

slides.setup_instructions: Lay the chain straight on the mat. Have arrow labels in a small bowl.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need our special bead chain that has 10 beads, some little arrow numbers, and a big mat to put it on. Can you ask your grown-up to help you find all these things so we can play?

slides.text: 'This is a bead chain! Let's stretch it out straight and count every single bead.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at our bead chain! Let's lay it down flat on the mat so it's nice and straight. Now, let's point to each bead and count them all together, one by one!

slides.text: Touch each bead: '1, 2, 3, 4, 5 — let's place the number 5 arrow here — 6, 7, 8, 9, 10!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's count again, and this time, when we get to the fifth bead, we'll say "five"! Then we'll keep going all the way to the last bead, which is number ten!

slides.text: Place the arrow labels at 5 and 10. 'These arrows help us keep track.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See these little arrows? They are like signs to help us remember where we are on our counting chain. We'll put one at number five and another one at the very end, number ten.

slides.text: 'We counted to 10! We can also skip count: 5... 10! That's counting by fives.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We counted all the way to ten, great job! Now, we can also count them a little differently, by jumping to number five, and then jumping to number ten! It's like a fun shortcut!

slides.prompt: Count the chain yourself. Place the arrow at 5 and at 10. Then try counting backward: 10, 9, 8...
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the super counter! Lay out your chain, count each bead, and put the arrows where they belong. Then, try counting backward from ten! You can do it!

slides.text: 'You counted the chain of 10! Soon we will count even longer chains.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child count the 10-bead chain accurately and place arrow labels?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You counted all 10 beads on our chain and used the arrows too! That was amazing counting, and soon we'll get to count even bigger chains!

parent_notes: Bead chains are a beautiful Montessori material for linear counting and skip counting. The chain of 10 is the starting point. Arrow labels mark key numbers and build number line awareness. Later the child will count chains of 100 and even 1000! If you don't have bead chains, string 10 beads on a shoelace or make a paper bead chain.

title: Bean Seed Observation — Day Check
description: Checking on the bean seed planted last week. The child observes changes, draws what they see, and records observations in a simple science journal.
instructions:
1. Retrieve the bean seed cup from the windowsill.
2. 'Has anything changed since we planted it? Let's look carefully!'
3. Use a magnifying glass to observe the seed closely.
4. If sprouted: 'Look! A root is growing DOWN and a sprout is growing UP!'
5. Draw today's observation in a simple science journal.
6. Measure the sprout if possible. Water if the paper towel is drying out.
materials_needed: Bean seed cup from last week

slides.heading: Bean Seed
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It says "Bean Seed" and "Observation Day." That means today we get to see how our little bean seed is doing! We planted it a while ago, and now we get to be super scientists and look at it.

slides.setup_instructions: Bring the seed cup and observation materials to the work area.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the fun things we need for our science adventure! We have our bean seed cup, a special magnifying glass to see tiny things, a journal to draw in, and some colorful crayons. Ask a grown-up to help you get them all ready!

slides.text: 'Let's check on our bean seed! Remember, we are watching the life cycle happen in real time.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, first things first! Let's go find our bean seed cup. Remember how we planted it? We're going to peek inside and see if our little seed has started to do something magical.

slides.text: Look closely with the magnifying glass. 'What do you see? Has the seed changed shape? Is anything growing?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for some super-duper looking! Grab your magnifying glass and let's get really close to our bean seed. What do you see? Has it changed shape at all? Is there anything new popping out?

slides.text: If sprouted: 'The root grows DOWN to find water. The sprout grows UP to find sunlight!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look! If you see something growing, that's so exciting! A little root is growing DOWN into the soil, like it's looking for a drink of water. And a little sprout is growing UP towards the sky, looking for sunshine!

slides.text: 'Let's draw what we see today. Scientists always record their observations.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Scientists love to draw what they see, just like we do! So, let's get our science journal and our crayons ready to draw exactly what our bean seed looks like right now. This is how we keep track of its amazing journey!

slides.prompt: Draw the bean seed as it looks today. Label what you see: seed, root, sprout. Is the paper towel still wet?
slides.mascot_explanation: For your drawing, can you show me the seed, and if you see it, the root going down and the sprout going up? It's also good to check if the paper towel is still a little wet, like a nice drink for our plant. You can do it!

slides.text: 'We will keep checking every few days. Your seed is growing! Just like the boy's carrot seed.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe what has changed and draw an accurate observation?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did such a great job being scientists today! You looked so closely and drew what you saw. Your bean seed is growing, just like in the story! We'll keep watching it grow more and more.

parent_notes: Regular observation is the heart of scientific thinking. Even if the seed hasn't changed much, the child practices looking carefully and recording. Dates on each drawing create a simple growth record. If the seed hasn't sprouted yet, reassure the child that it can take 3-7 days. If it appears the seed has not been successful, plant a new one — gardeners always plant extras!
household_substitutes: Bean seed cup from last week
preparation_steps: Review the lesson steps. Gather all materials before calling your child to the work area.
control_of_error: Observe the child — can they complete the activity independently?
extension_ideas: Repeat the lesson another day
Let the child show a family member what they learned
Connect this activity to daily life

title: Printmaking — Sponge Stamp Prints
description: Creating prints using sponge stamps cut into simple shapes. The child learns to dip, press, and lift to create repeating patterns.
instructions:
1. Pre-cut sponges into simple shapes: circle, square, triangle, star.
2. Pour thin layers of tempera paint into shallow dishes.
3. Demonstrate: dip the sponge lightly, press onto paper, lift straight up.
4. Show how to create a pattern: circle, square, circle, square.
5. Child creates their own prints and patterns.
6. Try overlapping shapes and mixing colors.

slides.heading: Printmaking
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! Today we're going to be artists and make super cool pictures using sponges. It's called "Printmaking" and it's going to be so much fun!

slides.setup_instructions: Cut sponges into shapes beforehand. Pour thin layers of paint. Cover the table.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's see what we need for our art adventure! We have sponges cut into fun shapes, like a circle and a star. We also have colorful paint in little dishes, and big white paper for our pictures. Oh, and don't forget your smock to keep your clothes clean and newspaper to protect our table! Can you ask a grown-up to help you gather all these things?

slides.text: 'Today we are making prints with sponge stamps! Look: a circle sponge, a square sponge, a triangle sponge.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at these special sponges! We have a round one like a ball, a square one like a block, and a pointy triangle one. These are our special stamps that will make pictures on the paper.

slides.text: Demonstrate: dip the sponge flat side into the paint. 'Not too much paint!' Press onto paper. Lift straight up. 'A circle print!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now watch me! We'll take our sponge, just touch the paint gently so it doesn't get too messy, and then press it down on the paper. See? When I lift it up, it makes a perfect circle print!

slides.text: 'Let's make a PATTERN! Circle, square, circle, square... What comes next?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try making a pattern together! We'll make a circle print, then a square print, then another circle print, and another square print. What shape do you think should come next to keep the pattern going?

slides.prompt: Create your own stamp prints! Make patterns, pictures, or just explore. Try mixing shapes and colors.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the artist! You can make any pictures you want using your sponge stamps. Try making patterns, or maybe a whole picture, and you can even mix the colors to see what happens!

slides.text: Let prints dry. Wash the sponges and clean up. 'You made beautiful patterns with prints!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create clear stamp prints and attempt a repeating pattern?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all the amazing pictures you made! Your prints look so beautiful, and you made such wonderful patterns. You are such a great artist, and we had so much fun making art together today!

parent_notes: Sponge printing connects art with math (patterns) and sensorial work (shapes). The pattern-making extends the child's mathematical thinking — recognizing and creating repeating patterns is a foundational math skill. Let the child also stamp freely without patterns. Keep the paint thin so prints are crisp rather than blobby.
preparation_steps: Review the lesson steps. Gather all materials before calling your child to the work area.
control_of_error: Observe the child — can they complete the activity independently?
extension_ideas: Repeat the lesson another day
Let the child show a family member what they learned
Connect this activity to daily life

title: Polishing — Mirror or Metal
description: The child learns to polish a small mirror or metal object. This exercise teaches care for the environment, attention to detail, and the satisfaction of restoring shine.
instructions:
1. Place materials on a tray: small mirror or metal object, polishing paste or cream, soft cloth, cotton balls, small bowl of water.
2. Demonstrate: dip cotton ball in polish, apply in small circles.
3. Let the polish sit briefly.
4. Buff with the dry cloth using circular motions.
5. 'Look at the shine! Can you see your reflection?'
6. Child polishes independently. Clean up all materials.
materials_needed: Small mirror or metal object (brass, silver, or copper)
Metal polish or baking soda paste

slides.heading: Polishing
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this title! It says "Polishing" and "Making Things Shine!" That means we're going to get something looking super bright and sparkly, just like magic!

slides.setup_instructions: Arrange all materials on a tray. Put on a smock. Choose a slightly tarnished piece for visible results.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's see what we need for our shining fun! We have a little mirror or metal thingy that's not so shiny right now, some special cream to make it clean, fluffy cotton balls, a soft cloth, and a little bowl of water. Oh, and a tray to keep everything tidy and a smock so our clothes stay clean! Ask your grown-up to help you gather all these treasures.

slides.text: 'Look at this piece — it's a bit dull. We are going to make it SHINE! This is called polishing.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this mirror! It looks a little bit cloudy, right? We're going to make it super shiny so it gleams. This special job is called polishing, and it's going to be so much fun to see it change!

slides.text: Dip a cotton ball in the polish. 'Apply it in small circles. Cover the whole surface.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we take a soft cotton ball and dip it gently into the special polish cream. Then, we'll carefully rub the cream all over the mirror in little circles, like we're drawing tiny swirls. We want to cover every little bit!

slides.text: Wait a moment, then take the dry cloth: 'Now we buff — rub in circles until it shines!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We let the polish sit for just a tiny moment, like it's taking a little nap. Then, we grab our dry, soft cloth and gently rub the mirror again in circles. We keep rubbing until we see it start to sparkle and shine!

slides.text: 'Look at the difference! One side is polished and one side is not. Can you see yourself in the shiny part?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look closely! Can you see how one part is shiny and you can almost see your face in it, but the other part is still a little dull? Polishing makes a big, big difference, doesn't it?

slides.prompt: Polish the entire piece. Work in small circles. Buff until you can see your reflection!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to make the whole mirror super shiny! Remember to rub in little circles with the polish, then use the cloth to buff it until you can see your happy face looking back at you. You've got this – make it gleam!

slides.text: Wash hands. Clean up all polishing materials. 'Beautiful work! You restored the shine.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete the polishing process: apply, wait, buff?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You made the mirror so shiny, and your hands are all clean now. You did such a beautiful job polishing, just like a super helper!

parent_notes: Polishing is a classic Montessori practical life exercise that teaches care for the environment. The before-and-after transformation is deeply satisfying. Use non-toxic polish or make your own with baking soda and water. Brass, copper, and silver pieces from thrift stores work perfectly. This work can be placed on a tray on the shelf for the child to repeat independently.
preparation_steps: Set up a cleaning station with all supplies organized left-to-right in order of use.
control_of_error: The surface shows if it is clean or still dirty — built-in feedback.
extension_ideas: Clean a mirror (fingerprints are visible feedback)
Wash a plant's leaves
Polish shoes or wooden items

title: CVC Word Reading — Picture to Word Matching
description: The child reads CVC word cards and matches each to its corresponding picture card. Building reading fluency and comprehension.
instructions:
1. Lay out 8 picture cards (sun, hat, pig, cup, bed, log, pen, van).
2. Show word cards one at a time.
3. Child reads the word: '/s/-/u/-/n/ — sun!' and places it next to the matching picture.
4. Continue until all 8 are matched.
5. Check work by reading each pair.
6. Extension: child draws their own pictures for 3 new words.

slides.heading: Reading Practice
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to have some super fun reading practice today. We'll be matching words to pictures, just like being a super detective for words!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay picture cards in two rows. Have word cards in a stack face down.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get ready for our game! We have some colorful pictures and some word cards. We also have a special mat and some paper and crayons for later. Can you help me find all these things with a grown-up?

slides.text: 'Here are some pictures. And here are word cards. Your job is to READ each word and match it to its picture!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, here are all the pretty pictures, and here are the word cards. Your job is to be a word detective! We're going to read each word and then find its matching picture.

slides.text: Turn over the first word card. 'Sound it out: /s/-/u/-/n/. Sun! Which picture shows a sun?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try one together! Let's flip over the first word card. Can you help me sound out the letters? /s/-/u/-/n/ — that says 'sun'! Now, let's find the picture that looks like a sun!

slides.text: Child reads each card independently and places it beside the matching picture. Offer help only if the child is stuck.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the word detective! Read each word card all by yourself and find its picture. If you get stuck, I'm right here to help you sound it out. You can do it!

slides.text: After all are matched, read through each pair: 'Sun — yes! Hat — yes!' Celebrate correct matches.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you matched them all up! Let's look together. Is this 'sun' with the sun picture? Yes! Is this 'hat' with the hat picture? Yes! You did such a great job matching!

slides.prompt: Match all 8 words to pictures. Then draw your own pictures for 3 new words: cat, box, rug.
slides.mascot_explanation: You are such a super reader! You read eight words all by yourself and matched them perfectly. Now for some extra fun, let's draw pictures for three new words: cat, box, and rug!

slides.text: 'You read 8 words all by yourself! You are becoming a reader!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently read and match at least 6 out of 8 words?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You read eight words today all by yourself and matched them to their pictures. That's amazing! You are a fantastic reader, and drawing your own pictures was super creative too!

parent_notes: Picture-word matching builds the connection between decoding (sounding out) and comprehension (understanding meaning). Watch the child's strategy — are they sounding out each word or beginning to recognize some by sight? Both strategies are developing. Make your own cards using index cards and simple drawings or magazine cutouts.

title: Golden Bead Introduction — Units, Tens, Hundreds
description: Introduction to the Montessori golden bead material. The child handles and names the three categories: unit bead, ten bar, and hundred square.
instructions:
1. Present one unit bead: 'This is ONE. One unit bead.'
2. Present a ten bar: 'This is TEN. Count the beads — ten beads all strung together.'
3. Present a hundred square: 'This is ONE HUNDRED. It's ten ten-bars put together!'
4. Three-period lesson: 'Show me ten. What is this? Give me one hundred.'
5. 'How many units in a ten?' (10) 'How many tens in a hundred?' (10)
6. Let the child handle and compare each freely.
materials_needed: Golden beads: units (loose beads), ten bars, hundred squares

slides.heading: Golden Beads
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to play with something super special called Golden Beads today! They help us learn about numbers, like how we count our toys.

slides.setup_instructions: Place each type on the tray, separated. Lay out a large work mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these shiny beads and squares! We have little single beads, long bars with beads, and big flat squares. We'll put them all on this mat to play.

slides.text: Hold up one golden bead: 'This is a UNIT. One single bead. It represents the number one.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this tiny little bead? This is called a 'unit,' and it's just like the number one. It's a single, special bead all by itself.

slides.text: Hold up a ten bar: 'This is a TEN BAR. Count the beads — there are ten beads strung together!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now look at this long stick of beads! This is a 'ten bar,' and it has ten beads all stuck together. Can you count them with me? That's right, ten!

slides.text: Hold up a hundred square: 'This is a HUNDRED SQUARE! Feel how many beads. Ten bars put side by side make one hundred!'
slides.mascot_explanation: And look at this big, flat square! This is a 'hundred square.' It's like ten of those ten bars put together to make something super big and special!

slides.text: Three-period lesson: 'This is a unit. Show me a ten bar. What is this?' (Hundred square!)
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's play a game! Can you point to the single bead? And what is this long one called? You're so smart!

slides.prompt: Exchange! Trade me: 10 unit beads for 1 ten bar. Trade 10 ten bars for 1 hundred square. Count to make sure!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to trade! We can swap ten little beads for one long bar, and ten long bars for one big square. Let's count them all together to make sure it's fair!

slides.text: 'Units, tens, hundreds — these golden beads help us understand big numbers! Next we'll use them together.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and distinguish unit beads, ten bars, and hundred squares?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job with the golden beads! You learned about ones, tens, and hundreds, which are like building blocks for big numbers. We'll play with them again soon!

parent_notes: The golden bead material is one of the most important Montessori math materials. It makes the decimal system tangible: the child can hold 1, feel the weight of 10, and appreciate the size of 100. The exchange game (10 units = 1 ten, 10 tens = 1 hundred) is the foundation for carrying in addition and regrouping in subtraction. If you don't have golden beads, use base-10 blocks (units cubes, ten rods, hundred flats).

title: Community Helpers — Introduction
description: Introduction to community helpers: people who work to help our community function. Exploring the roles of firefighters, doctors, teachers, and mail carriers.
instructions:
1. 'A community is all the people who live and work near us. Some people have jobs that help everyone!'
2. Show pictures of community helpers: firefighter, doctor, teacher, mail carrier.
3. Discuss each: 'What does a firefighter do? Why is their job important?'
4. 'What tools does each helper use?'
5. Sort picture cards by helper type.
6. 'Who are the helpers in YOUR community?'
materials_needed: Community helper picture cards or photos

slides.heading: Community Helpers
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this big title! It says "Community Helpers" and that means people who help us all live together nicely. We're going to learn about some very special friends today!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out helper cards. Have tool cards ready for matching activity.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these fun cards! We have pictures of our helpers, and then pictures of their special tools. We also have a big mat to help us put them all in the right places.

slides.text: 'Many people work to help our community. Let's learn about some of them!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Our teacher is going to show us some amazing people who have important jobs. They all help make our neighborhood a super happy and safe place for everyone!

slides.text: Show firefighter: 'Firefighters put out fires and keep us safe. They use fire trucks, hoses, and special gear.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this brave person? This is a firefighter! They zoom in a big red truck and use a long hose to put out fires, keeping us all safe.

slides.text: Show doctor: 'Doctors help us when we are sick. They use stethoscopes and medicine.' Continue with teacher and mail carrier.
slides.mascot_explanation: And here's a doctor! When we feel a little ouchie or sick, doctors help us feel better. They listen to our hearts with a special tool called a stethoscope. We'll also meet teachers and mail carriers!

slides.text: 'Each helper has special TOOLS for their job.' Match tool cards to helpers.
slides.mascot_explanation: All these helpers have special things they use for their jobs, like tools! We're going to be detectives and figure out which tool belongs to which helper.

slides.prompt: Match each tool to its community helper. Then draw a picture of yourself as a community helper. What would you be?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a helper detective! We'll match each tool card to the right community helper. Then, you get to draw a picture of what you want to be when you grow up to help everyone!

slides.text: 'Our community works because all these helpers do their jobs. We all help each other!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 3 community helpers and describe what they do?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job learning about our community helpers today! You helped match all the tools and even drew a picture of yourself as a helper. Remember, everyone helps each other!

parent_notes: Community helper studies connect children to the real world and build social awareness. Point out helpers in your daily life: the crossing guard, the librarian, the bus driver. If possible, arrange visits or video calls with community helpers. Children's books about different occupations extend this learning beautifully.

title: Read-Aloud: Flower Garden by Eve Bunting
description: Reading 'Flower Garden' by Eve Bunting, a story about a child who creates a window box flower garden as a birthday surprise for her mother.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'What are they carrying? Where do you think they're going?'
2. Read the rhythmic text, pointing to the shopping and planting process.
3. Name the flowers: marigolds, pansies, daisies.
4. Discuss the surprise element: 'How do you think the mother will feel?'
5. Connect to our plant studies: 'What does the girl plant? What do plants need?'
6. 'Have you ever given someone a surprise?'

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to read a book called "Flower Garden" by Eve Bunting. It's a special story about a surprise garden!

slides.setup_instructions: Sit together comfortably.
slides.mascot_explanation: To read our story, we need our book and a super cozy spot to snuggle up. Can you help me find a comfy place to sit together?

slides.text: Show the cover: 'A girl and her dad are carrying a box on the bus. What could be inside?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at the front of the book! See the girl and her dad carrying a box on the bus? What do you think is inside their surprise box?

slides.text: Read with rhythm and warmth. Point out the progression: shopping, bus ride, planting, surprise.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we're going to read the story together! As we read, we'll see them go shopping, ride the bus, and plant their special flowers.

slides.text: After reading: 'The flower box was a birthday surprise! How did the mother feel?'
slides.mascot_explanation: The story tells us the flowers were a surprise birthday gift! How happy do you think the mommy was when she saw the beautiful flowers?

slides.prompt: 'What flowers would YOU plant in a window box? Draw your own flower garden and tell me about it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's pretend we're planting our own garden! What colors and kinds of flowers would you put in your window box? Maybe you can draw them for me!

slides.text: 'Gardens can be anywhere — even in a window box! A garden made with love is a wonderful gift.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the sequence of events and connect to plant care knowledge?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wasn't that fun? We learned that even a small garden in a window can be a big surprise, especially when it's made with love. You did so great listening to the story!

parent_notes: This book beautifully shows urban gardening and the joy of giving. It continues the plant theme and adds an emotional/social dimension. The rhyming text is predictable and engaging. If you have space, create a small window box garden together — even herbs in a kitchen window count. This connects practical life, botany, and social-emotional learning.
household_substitutes: The book mentioned in the lesson
preparation_steps: Choose a cozy spot. Preview the book before reading it aloud.
control_of_error: Discussion-based — ask open-ended questions about the story.
extension_ideas: Draw a favorite scene
Retell the story in your own words
Act out a scene together

title: Constructive Triangles — Second Box (Blue Triangles Without Lines)
description: Working with constructive triangles without black guiding lines. The child must figure out how to combine triangles to make shapes using only visual judgment.
instructions:
1. Present the second set of constructive triangles (no black lines).
2. 'Remember how triangles can make other shapes? This time there are no lines to guide you!'
3. Start with two right triangles. 'Can you make a rectangle?'
4. Try making a square from two triangles.
5. Try making a larger triangle from two smaller ones.
6. Challenge: create as many different shapes as possible.
materials_needed: Constructive Triangles — set without guide lines

slides.heading: Constructive Triangles
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to play with special triangle shapes today. They are all different colors and sizes for us to explore.

slides.setup_instructions: Spread the triangles on the mat. Have the lined set nearby if the child needs to reference it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these colorful triangles! We also have a special mat to put them on. Can you help your grown-up find these triangles and the mat so we can start our fun game?

slides.text: 'Last time, the black lines showed us where to join. This time, you have to figure it out with your EYES!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we used triangles with lines before? This time, the triangles don't have any lines to help us. We get to use our smart eyes to figure out how they fit together!

slides.text: Hand the child two right triangles: 'Can you make a rectangle? Try matching the long edges together.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's take two of these triangles. See how they have a long side? Try to put those long sides together and see what new shape you can make! Maybe it looks like a door!

slides.text: 'Now make a square! And can you make a bigger triangle from two smaller ones?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's try something else! Can you put two triangles together to make a square, like a window? And can you use two triangles to make one big triangle? You're a super shape maker!

slides.text: 'What about a diamond shape? Or a hexagon? Experiment with different combinations.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's be super explorers! Can you try putting different triangles together to make a diamond shape, or even a hexagon, like a stop sign? Let's see how many new shapes we can discover!

slides.prompt: Create as many different shapes as you can from triangles. Name each shape you make!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our special shape-making time! Take your triangles and try to build as many different shapes as you can. When you make a new shape, tell us its name! You can do it!

slides.text: 'You made shapes without any guide lines! Your eyes and hands knew what to do.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child form at least 3 shapes without guide lines?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did it! You made so many amazing shapes using just your eyes and hands, no lines needed! You are such a clever shape builder, and making those new shapes was super cool!

parent_notes: Removing the guide lines adds a layer of challenge. The child must use spatial reasoning and visual judgment to determine which edges match. This progresses from concrete (with lines) to more abstract (without). If the child is frustrated, briefly show the lined version as a reference, then return to the unlined set. This work builds geometry intuition.

title: CVC Word Reading — Action Cards
description: The child reads CVC action words and performs the action. This multi-sensory approach connects reading to physical movement and comprehension.
instructions:
1. Write action words on cards: sit, hop, run, dig, hug, nod, tap, rub, pat, jog.
2. 'These words tell you to DO something. Read the word and then DO it!'
3. Child picks a card, reads it, and performs the action.
4. Continue through all cards.
5. Child makes their own action cards for family members.
6. Play 'Simon Says' using the cards.
materials_needed: Blank cards and marker for child to make their own

slides.heading: Reading in Action!
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this fun title! It says "Reading in Action!" That means we're going to read words and then we get to DO things, like running and jumping. It's going to be so much fun to move our bodies while we learn!

slides.setup_instructions: Write action words clearly on cards. Clear space for movement.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, friend, let's see what we need for our amazing action game! We have these special word cards here, and we also need a nice open space so we can move around. We'll also need some blank cards and a marker to make our *own* special action words later! Ask your grown-up to help you get these ready.

slides.text: 'Today reading is going to make us MOVE! Read the word and then DO what it says!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our super important first step! It says that reading these words is going to make us move our bodies. So when we see a word, we'll read it with our eyes and then we'll do the action with our feet and hands! It's like magic words that tell us what to do.

slides.text: Hold up 'hop': 'Sound it out: /h/-/o/-/p/. Hop! Now HOP!' Child hops.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this card! It has the word "hop" on it. Let's sound it out together: /h/-/o/-/p/. That spells "hop"! Now, let's do it! Can you hop like a bunny? Boing, boing! Great job!

slides.text: Continue with: sit, run, dig, hug, nod, tap, rub, pat, jog. Act out each word!
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to do this for all the cards! We'll read words like "sit," "run," and "dig," and then we'll pretend to do them. So if the card says "sit," we'll sit down. If it says "run," we'll pretend to run really fast! It's like acting out a little play with words.

slides.text: 'Reading tells us what to DO. Words have meaning — and these words mean ACTION!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super cool reminder! It says that words can tell us to do things. When we read these action words, they are like little instructions for our bodies. Reading is so powerful because it helps us understand and do all sorts of fun things!

slides.prompt: Pick cards from the pile and do each action. Then make 3 new action word cards for your family to try!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the boss! We'll pick a card, read the word, and do the action. After we do all the cards, we get to be creative and make three *new* action word cards for someone else to try! It will be so much fun to see what words you choose.

slides.text: 'You read words and brought them to life! Reading is powerful — it tells us things!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read and act out at least 7 out of 10 action words?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You read so many words and you did all the actions! You brought those words to life with your amazing body. Reading is super powerful because it told you exactly what to do and you did it perfectly! You are such a great reader!

parent_notes: Action reading cards are one of the most engaging Montessori reading activities. They prove to the child that reading has PURPOSE — the written word makes things happen! This is Montessori's concept of 'total reading' — connecting decoding to meaning. Make it a family game where everyone takes turns picking and performing cards. Children love being in charge of what adults do!

title: Golden Beads — Building Numbers (11-99)
description: Using golden beads and numeral cards to build two-digit numbers. The child combines ten bars and unit beads to represent numbers concretely.
instructions:
1. Review: unit = 1, ten bar = 10.
2. 'Let's build the number 23!' Place 2 ten bars and 3 unit beads.
3. Match with numeral cards: place the '20' card and the '3' card, overlapping to show '23.'
4. Build more: 15, 34, 47, 52, 68.
5. I say a number, child builds with beads AND cards.
6. Extension: child builds a number, I guess what it is.
materials_needed: Golden bead units and ten bars

slides.heading: Golden Beads
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to learn how to make big numbers using these shiny golden beads. It's like building with blocks, but for numbers!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out ten bars and units in organized groups. Have numeral cards stacked by category.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these special things we need for our math game! We have long sticks that are like ten friends holding hands (those are ten bars!), and little tiny beads that are just one by themselves. We also have big number cards, and a special mat to build on. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these things?

slides.text: 'Today we are going to build bigger numbers! Let's start with 23. How many tens? TWO. How many units? THREE.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today, we're going to build a number called twenty-three! That means we need two groups of ten, and then three little ones. Can you see how many tens we need? That's right, two! And how many little ones? Yes, three!

slides.text: Place 2 ten bars and 3 unit beads on the mat. 'Two tens and three units — twenty-three!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's put our beads on the mat to make twenty-three! We put two long ten bars here, and then three little beads right next to them. See? It looks like twenty-three!

slides.text: Show the numeral cards: the '20' card and the '3' card. Overlay them: '23! The beads and the numbers match.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we match our beads with the number cards! We have a card that says "twenty" and a card that says "three." When we put them together, they make "twenty-three," just like our beads!

slides.text: 'Let's build 47.' Child places 4 ten bars and 7 units. Finds '40' card and '7' card. Overlays: 47!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try another one! We're going to build the number forty-seven. Can you find four long ten bars and seven little beads? Then, we'll find the "forty" card and the "seven" card and put them together.

slides.prompt: Build these numbers with beads AND cards: 15, 34, 52, 68, 91. Then make up your own numbers for me to guess!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the builder! Can you make the number fifteen using the beads and the number cards? Then try thirty-four, fifty-two, and sixty-eight. After that, you can make up your own number and I'll try to guess it!

slides.text: 'You can build any number from 1 to 99 with golden beads! The beads SHOW the number.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build at least 4 two-digit numbers with both beads and cards?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job building numbers today! You learned that the golden beads can show us any number from one all the way up to ninety-nine. It's like you have a secret code to make numbers!

parent_notes: This lesson connects concrete quantity (beads) with the abstract symbol (numerals). The overlapping cards are key — the child sees that 23 is made of '20' plus '3.' This is place value made visible. Don't rush past this work; it builds the deep understanding needed for all multi-digit math. If you don't have golden beads, use base-10 blocks or even bundles of straws (10 straws bundled together = ten).

title: Flags — Drawing and Coloring
description: The child selects flags to study, draws them carefully, and colors them with the correct colors. Building cultural awareness and fine motor skills.
instructions:
1. Review flags from last week.
2. Present 3-4 new flags: France, India, South Africa, Australia.
3. Show each flag and name the country. Find it on the map.
4. Discuss colors and symbols: 'India has a wheel in the center. Australia has stars.'
5. Child selects 2 flags to draw and color carefully.
6. Label each flag with the country name.

slides.heading: Flags of the World
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun page! It says "Flags of the World," and we're going to learn all about them and make some pretty pictures!

slides.setup_instructions: Display flag cards. Have drawing materials ready. Open the world map.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need for our special flag adventure! We have colorful flag pictures, paper to draw on, crayons to color with, a big map of the world, and a special ruler to help us draw straight lines. Let's ask a grown-up to help us find all of these treasures!

slides.text: Review: 'Last week we learned about flags. What flags do you remember?' Show the old cards.
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember last week when we looked at flags? Let's take a peek at some of them again and see if you can remember which country belongs to which flag. It's like a fun memory game!

slides.text: New flags: 'France has three vertical stripes: blue, white, red.' Find France on the map.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to meet some new friends! This is the flag of France, and it has three big stripes: blue, white, and red. Can you help find France on our big world map?

slides.text: 'India has three horizontal stripes: orange, white, green — with a blue wheel in the center!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the flag of India! It has stripes of orange, white, and green, and right in the middle is a pretty blue wheel. Isn't that neat?

slides.text: 'Choose your two favorite flags to draw. Use a ruler for straight lines. Color carefully with the right colors.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be an artist! Look at all these beautiful flags, and pick your two very favorites to draw. We can use the ruler to make our lines super straight, and then color them just like the real flags.

slides.prompt: Draw and color two flags. Try to make them look just like the real ones! Write the country name below each.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make some art! Let's draw those two flags you picked and color them with all the right colors. Try your best to make them look like the pictures, and then we'll write the country's name underneath. You've got this!

slides.text: 'Beautiful flags! Each flag tells us about a country's history and values.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child draw recognizable flags with correct colors and name the countries?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! Look at the wonderful flags you drew and colored! Each one is like a special picture telling us about a faraway place. You did such a great job making them look so good and learning their names!

parent_notes: Flag drawing combines geography, art, and fine motor skills. The use of a ruler for straight lines develops precision. Don't expect perfect results — the effort and engagement matter. Start a flag collection book where the child adds new flags each week. This can become a yearlong project that the child takes pride in.

title: Watercolor — Painting a Sunset
description: Guided watercolor painting of a sunset using wet-on-wet technique. The child practices blending warm colors: red, orange, yellow.
instructions:
1. Show a picture of a sunset. 'What colors do you see?'
2. Wet the paper with the sponge.
3. Start at the top with red/dark orange. 'Paint across in gentle strokes.'
4. Below that, paint regular orange. Then yellow at the bottom.
5. 'Watch the colors blend where they meet! That's how sunsets look.'
6. When dry, optionally add a black silhouette (trees, mountains) with marker.

slides.heading: Watercolor Painting
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to make a beautiful sunset picture using special paint called watercolors. It will be so much fun to see all the pretty colors we can make together!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up painting area. Wet the paper. Have a sunset photo for reference.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we need for our painting adventure! We have paints with bright colors, a special paper, a brush to move the paint, and a cup for water. There's also a sponge to make the paper wet, and a smock to keep your clothes clean. Let's ask a grown-up to help us find all these things!

slides.text: 'Sunsets have the most beautiful colors! Let's paint one. We'll start with the darkest color at the top.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Sunsets are so amazing, aren't they? We're going to make our own sunset picture, and we'll start at the very top with the darkest, prettiest colors. We'll use our brush to paint across the top of our paper, just like this!

slides.text: Wet the paper. Paint dark red/orange across the top with broad strokes.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's make the paper a little bit wet with our sponge – see how it makes the paper shiny? This helps the colors mix together like magic! Then, we'll take our red and orange paint and make a stripe right across the top of our wet paper.

slides.text: Below that, paint bright orange. Below that, yellow. 'Watch the colors blend into each other!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, we'll paint a stripe of bright orange right under the red, and then a stripe of sunny yellow at the very bottom. Watch closely as the colors touch each other – they will start to mix and blend, just like a real sunset in the sky!

slides.prompt: Paint your own sunset! Let the colors blend on the wet paper. When dry, you can add tree silhouettes with black marker.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make your very own sunset! Remember to paint your red, then orange, then yellow stripes, and watch them all blend together on the wet paper. When it's all dry, you can even draw some trees or mountains at the bottom with the black marker if you want!

slides.text: Let dry. 'Your sunset is beautiful! Every sunset is different — just like your painting.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a blended warm-color painting?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! Look at your beautiful sunset painting! You did such a wonderful job mixing all those warm colors together. Every sunset is special and looks a little different, and your painting is special and beautiful, just like you!

parent_notes: A sunset painting is a wonderful guided project because it's almost impossible to 'fail' — blended warm colors naturally look beautiful. This builds confidence with watercolors. The optional silhouette (trees, hills) adds a second step and the contrast between flowing color and sharp lines. Frame this one — it makes a lovely gift!
household_substitutes: Cup of water and paper towels
preparation_steps: Cover the work surface. Set out materials in order of use. Demonstrate technique first.
control_of_error: Art is self-expressive — focus on the process, not the product.
extension_ideas: Display the artwork proudly
Try the same subject with a different medium
Look at famous artwork for inspiration

title: Sewing — Stitching a Shape
description: The child sews along a simple shape (circle or heart) drawn on burlap, building on the running stitch learned last week.
instructions:
1. Draw a simple shape (circle, heart, or star) on the burlap with marker.
2. Thread the needle and tie a knot.
3. Child sews along the shape using the running stitch.
4. 'Follow the line! Up, down, up, down along the shape.'
5. When the shape is complete, tie off the thread.
6. The child may outline another shape with a different color yarn.

slides.heading: Sewing
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our sewing lesson! We are going to learn how to stitch a fun shape.

slides.setup_instructions: Draw a shape on the burlap. Thread the needle. Secure burlap in hoop if available.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all the cool things we need! We have some bumpy burlap with a shape on it, a needle all ready with thread, and some colorful yarn. We might also use a hoop to hold our burlap tight. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these things!

slides.text: 'Last time you sewed a straight line. Today you will sew along a SHAPE! See the circle I drew?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Last time we sewed a straight line, remember? Well, today we get to sew around a shape! See this pretty circle on our burlap? We are going to trace it with our needle and thread.

slides.text: 'Start at any point on the line. Use the running stitch: up, down, up, down. Follow the curve!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's start sewing! We'll put our needle through the burlap and then back down, going up and down, up and down, right on the line. It's like drawing with a needle!

slides.text: 'Curves are trickier than straight lines. Take small stitches around the curve for a smooth look.'
slides.mascot_explanation: When we get to a bendy part, we need to be super careful. Let's make our stitches a little smaller, like tiny steps, so we can follow the curve smoothly. This will make our shape look extra neat!

slides.prompt: Sew around the entire shape. When finished, try a second shape with a different color yarn!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to shine! Let's sew all the way around the shape we drew, going up and down, up and down. When you finish this one, we can even try sewing another shape with a different color yarn!

slides.text: Tie off the thread. 'You sewed a shape! Your stitching is getting better and better.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sew along a curved shape with relatively even stitches?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You sewed all around the shape, and look how neat it is! Your stitches are getting so good, and you are becoming a super sewing star.

parent_notes: Sewing curves is harder than straight lines because the child must adjust the needle direction. This builds spatial awareness. If the child finds curves too difficult, draw a square or triangle instead (straight edges). Save these sewing samples to track progress over time. Many children become deeply absorbed in sewing work — it is wonderfully meditative.
household_substitutes: Large plastic needle or blunt tapestry needle
preparation_steps: Pre-punch holes in the fabric or card. Thread the needle and tie a knot at the end.
control_of_error: The stitching pattern shows whether the child followed the path correctly.
extension_ideas: Sew a simple pouch or felt ornament
Create a sewing card from cardboard
Practice different stitch patterns

title: Phonetic Booklets — Reading Short Books
description: The child reads their first simple phonetic booklet — a tiny book with one CVC sentence per page and matching illustrations.
instructions:
1. Present a simple phonetic booklet (2-4 pages, one sentence each).
2. 'This is a little BOOK! You are going to read a whole book today!'
3. Page 1: child reads the sentence. Discuss the picture.
4. Continue through all pages.
5. 'You read a whole book!'
6. Child reads the book to a stuffed animal or family member.
materials_needed: Phonetic booklets or simple CVC readers (2-3 books)

slides.heading: Phonetic Booklets
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We get to read a book today! It's a special book that you can read all by yourself.

slides.setup_instructions: Select books with CVC words and simple sentences. Sit together comfortably.
slides.mascot_explanation: To read our book, we need a few things! We need these little books with words and pictures, and a comfy spot to sit. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find them?

slides.text: 'Today is special — you are going to read a BOOK! A whole book, all by yourself.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today is a super special day because you are going to read a whole book! You are going to be a reader!

slides.text: Open to page 1. 'Sound out each word. Take your time.' Child reads: 'The cat sat on a mat.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's open our book to the first page. We will look at the words and say them very slowly, like a detective finding clues. The words say, "The cat sat on a mat."
