slides.text: Look at the picture. 'Does the picture match what you read? Yes! The cat IS sitting on a mat!'
slides.mascot_explanation: See the picture? It shows a cat sitting on a mat! Does that match the words we just read? Yes, it does! You did it!

slides.text: Continue through each page. Offer help only if the child is truly stuck. Let them work it out.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we will go to the next page, and then the next! We'll read all the words and look at all the pictures. If you get a little stuck, that's okay, we can try to figure it out together!

slides.prompt: Read the book once more — this time to a stuffed animal or family member! You are the reader now!
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you read the whole book! Now, let's read it one more time to your favorite teddy bear or to a grown-up. You get to be the teacher this time!

slides.text: 'YOU READ A BOOK! You are a READER! This is just the beginning — there are so many books waiting for you.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read a simple phonetic booklet with CVC words?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You read a whole book! You are such a super reader, and this is just the start of all the amazing books you will read!

parent_notes: Reading a first book is a major milestone — celebrate it! Phonetic booklets are specifically designed with only decodable words the child has learned. If you don't have Montessori phonetic booklets, look for Bob Books, Teach Your Monster to Read printable books, or make your own with simple sentences and drawings. Reading to others (a pet, a sibling, a stuffed animal) builds confidence and fluency.

title: Golden Beads — The Thousand Cube
description: Introduction to the thousand cube — completing the golden bead hierarchy. The child sees the progression from unit to ten to hundred to thousand.
instructions:
1. Review: unit bead, ten bar, hundred square.
2. 'What do you think comes next?' Reveal the thousand cube!
3. 'Ten hundred squares stacked together make ONE THOUSAND!'
4. Let the child hold and feel the weight.
5. Line up the progression: unit, ten bar, hundred square, thousand cube.
6. 'One, ten, one hundred, one THOUSAND!'

slides.heading: Golden Beads
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to learn about something super special called the "Thousand Cube" today! It's going to be so much fun exploring numbers together.

slides.setup_instructions: Have all four categories ready. Keep the thousand cube hidden for the reveal.
slides.mascot_explanation: To play our game, we need some special friends! We have a tiny little bead, a stick with ten beads, a flat square with lots of beads, and a big, big cube. We also need a soft mat to put them on. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find them all?

slides.text: Review the progression: 'One unit bead. One ten bar — that's 10 units. One hundred square — that's 10 tens.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's remember our number friends! We have one little bead, then a stick that's like ten tiny beads all together, and then a flat square that's like ten sticks all together. We've learned about these before!

slides.text: 'The pattern is: each one is TEN times bigger! So what comes after a hundred? TEN hundreds!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think! If each number friend is ten times bigger than the last one, what do you think comes after our flat square? It's like having ten of those flat squares all stacked up!

slides.text: Reveal the thousand cube: 'This is ONE THOUSAND! Feel how heavy it is. That's 1000 beads!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Ta-da! Look at this amazing giant cube! This is what happens when you have ten of the flat squares stacked up – it makes one whole THOUSAND! It feels so heavy because it has so many beads inside!

slides.text: Line them up: unit, ten, hundred, thousand. 'See how they grow? 1, 10, 100, 1000!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's put all our number friends in a line, from the smallest to the biggest. We have our little bead, then the stick, then the flat square, and now our giant thousand cube! See how they get bigger and bigger?

slides.prompt: Hold each one. Which is heaviest? Line them up from smallest to largest. Can you count: 1, 10, 100, 1000?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to play! Pick up each number friend and feel how heavy it is – which one is the heaviest? Then, let's line them up from smallest to biggest and try to say "one, ten, one hundred, one thousand!"

slides.text: 'One, ten, one hundred, one THOUSAND! You know the whole golden bead family!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name all four categories and order them from smallest to largest?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You learned about one, ten, one hundred, and even one THOUSAND! You know all the golden bead family members now, and you can show them from smallest to biggest. That's amazing!

parent_notes: The thousand cube is awe-inspiring for young children. Its weight and size make 'one thousand' real. The progression from tiny unit bead to massive thousand cube demonstrates the power of our decimal system. Let the child handle the materials freely. Some children will want to count individual beads on the thousand cube — encourage this! It takes a long time and builds persistence.

title: Seasons — Winter and Spring
description: Exploring the characteristics of winter and spring. The child learns what happens in nature during these two seasons and compares them.
instructions:
1. Show pictures of winter scenes: snow, bare trees, animals hibernating.
2. 'In winter, it's cold. Trees lose leaves. Some animals sleep all winter — this is called hibernation.'
3. Show pictures of spring: flowers blooming, baby animals, rain.
4. 'In spring, it gets warmer. Flowers grow. Animals have babies.'
5. Sort picture cards into winter and spring categories.
6. 'Which season are we in right now?'

slides.heading: The Seasons
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "The Seasons," and we're going to learn all about two special times of the year: Winter and Spring! They are like different moods for our Earth.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up two sorting areas labeled Winter and Spring. Spread picture cards face up.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we get to play with some fun things! We have these pretty picture cards, a special mat to put them on, and labels that say "Winter" and "Spring." We'll also use paper and crayons to draw, so ask a grown-up to help you find them all!

slides.text: 'Our Earth has seasons — times of the year when the weather changes. Let's learn about WINTER first.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Did you know our Earth has different "seasons" that change the weather? It's true! Today, we're going to start by learning all about the season called Winter. Let's get ready to explore it!

slides.text: Show winter pictures: 'Snow, cold, bare trees, short days, animals hibernating. Winter is a resting time.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at these pictures! In Winter, it gets very cold, and sometimes we see fluffy snow! Trees might not have many leaves, and some animals take a long nap. Winter is a cozy time when nature rests.

slides.text: Show spring pictures: 'Rain, flowers blooming, baby birds, longer days. Spring is a waking-up time!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now look at these pictures! This is Spring! It starts to get a little warmer, and beautiful flowers pop out of the ground. We might see little baby animals and hear the rain. Spring is when everything wakes up and starts to grow!

slides.text: 'Winter and spring are very different! Let's sort these pictures.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See how different winter and spring look? One is cold and sleepy, and the other is warm and growing! Now, we're going to be super smart scientists and sort these pictures to show which ones belong to Winter and which ones belong to Spring.

slides.prompt: Sort all the pictures into Winter and Spring. Then draw your favorite season. What do you like about it?
slides.mascot_explanation: It’s time to play! Look at all the picture cards. Let’s put the Winter pictures on the Winter side and the Spring pictures on the Spring side. After we sort them, we get to draw a picture of our favorite season and tell everyone why we like it best! You can do it!

slides.text: 'After winter comes spring — cold turns to warm, and everything starts growing again!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe 3 characteristics of winter and 3 of spring?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned all about Winter and Spring. Remember how Winter is cold and sleepy, and Spring is warm and full of growing things? You are so smart for learning all about the seasons!

parent_notes: Seasons are best taught through direct observation, so connect these lessons to what the child sees outside. 'The trees are bare right now — that's a sign of winter.' If you live in a place without dramatic seasons, use pictures and videos. The four seasons will be revisited multiple times throughout the year. A seasonal nature table that changes with the seasons makes this concrete.
preparation_steps: Review the lesson steps. Gather all materials before calling your child to the work area.
control_of_error: Observe the child — can they complete the activity independently?
extension_ideas: Repeat the lesson another day
Let the child show a family member what they learned
Connect this activity to daily life

title: Printmaking — Vegetable Stamps
description: Creating prints using cut vegetables. The child discovers the hidden patterns inside vegetables by using them as stamps.
instructions:
1. Cut vegetables in half to reveal cross-sections: bell pepper, celery bunch, mushroom, potato (cut a shape into it), corn cob.
2. Dip the flat cut side into tempera paint.
3. Press onto paper and lift — reveal the print!
4. 'Look at the star inside the pepper! The circles inside the celery!'
5. Create a vegetable print composition.
6. Label which vegetable made each print.

slides.heading: Printmaking
slides.mascot_explanation: Hi friend! Today we get to be artists and make pretty pictures using yummy vegetables. We're going to use them like stamps to make cool designs on paper. It's going to be so much fun!

items: Halved vegetables: pepper, celery, mushroom, potato, corn
slides.setup_instructions: Cut vegetables before the lesson. Pour paint into shallow dishes. Cover the work area.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all the things we need for our art project! We have some vegetables that have been cut so we can see their shapes inside, like a pepper and some celery. We also have colorful paint and paper for stamping, and a smock to keep your clothes clean. Ask a grown-up to help you gather all these special things!

slides.text: 'Look inside this pepper — there's a star shape! And these celery stalks make circles! Vegetables have hidden patterns.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look inside the pepper! Can you see the star shape hiding there? And the celery makes little circles, like tiny donuts! It's so cool that vegetables have secret pictures inside them.

slides.text: Dip the flat side of the pepper into paint. Press it onto paper. Lift carefully. 'A flower shape!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to use our vegetable stamp! Let's dip the flat part of the pepper into the paint, just a little bit. Then, we'll press it down gently on the paper and lift it up. Ta-da! Look, we made a beautiful flower shape!

slides.text: Try each vegetable. 'Which one makes the most interesting print? Are you surprised by any shapes?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try stamping with all our different vegetables now. We can dip the celery, the mushroom, and the potato in the paint too. Which one makes the prettiest print? Are you surprised by any of the shapes we find?

slides.prompt: Make prints with all the vegetables. Create a design or picture using the different shapes!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make a super cool picture using all our vegetable stamps! We can make a garden, or a funny monster, or anything you can imagine. Let's use all the different shapes to make our very own artwork!

slides.text: 'Vegetables have beautiful hidden shapes inside them. Nature is full of art!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create clear vegetable prints and identify which vegetable made each print?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job making art with vegetables! You discovered all the hidden shapes inside and made such beautiful prints. Isn't it amazing that we can find art in everyday things like vegetables?

parent_notes: Vegetable printing combines art with nature observation. The cross-sections reveal patterns the child has never noticed: the star inside a pepper, the fractal pattern in broccoli, the circles in celery. This connects to botany and develops observational skills. Use vegetables that are past their prime — this is a great way to use up produce that's too old for eating.
preparation_steps: Review the lesson steps. Gather all materials before calling your child to the work area.
